180â†’
   181â†’- [Claude Code Flow](https://github.com/ruvnet/claude-code-flow) by [ruvnet](https://github.com/ruvnet) - This mode serves as a code-first orchestration layer, enabling Claude to write, edit, test, and optimize code autonomously across recursive agent cycles.
   182â†’- [Claude Squad](https://github.com/smtg-ai/claude-squad) by [smtg-ai](https://github.com/smtg-ai) - Claude Squad is a terminal app that manages multiple Claude Code, Codex (and other local agents including Aider) in separate workspaces, allowing you to work on multiple tasks simultaneously.
   183â†’- [Claude Swarm](https://github.com/parruda/claude-swarm) by [parruda](https://github.com/parruda) - Launch Claude Code session that is connected to a swarm of Claude Code Agents.
   184â†’- [Claude Task Master](https://github.com/eyaltoledano/claude-task-master) by [eyaltoledano](https://github.com/eyaltoledano) - A task management system for AI-driven development with Claude, designed to work seamlessly with Cursor AI.
   185â†’- [Claude Task Runner](https://github.com/grahama1970/claude-task-runner) by [grahama1970](https://github.com/grahama1970) - A specialized tool to manage context isolation and focused task execution with Claude Code, solving the critical challenge of context length limitations and task focus when working with Claude on complex, multi-step projects.
   186â†’- [Happy Coder](https://github.com/slopus/happy) by [GrocerPublishAgent](https://peoplesgrocers.com/en/projects) - Spawn and control multiple Claude Codes in parallel from your phone or desktop. Happy Coder runs Claude Code on your hardware, sends push notifications when Claude needs more input or permission, and costs nothing.
   187â†’- [The Agentic Startup](https://github.com/rsmdt/the-startup) by [Rudolf Schmidt](https://github.com/rsmdt) - Yet Another Claude Orchestrator - a collection of agents, commands, etc., for shipping production code - but I like this because it's comprehensive, well-written, and one of the few resources that actually uses Output Styles! +10 points!
   188â†’- [TSK - AI Agent Task Manager and Sandbox](https://github.com/dtormoen/tsk) by [dtormoen](https://github.com/dtormoen) - A Rust CLI tool that lets you delegate development tasks to AI agents running in sandboxed Docker environments. Multiple agents work in parallel, returning git branches for human review.
   189â†’
   190â†’<br>
   191â†’
   192â†’## Status Lines ğŸ“Š
   193â†’
   194â†’> Status lines - Configurations and customizations for Claude Code's status bar functionality
   195â†’
   196â†’### General
   197â†’
   198â†’- [CCometixLine - Claude Code Statusline](https://github.com/Haleclipse/CCometixLine) by [Haleclipse](https://github.com/Haleclipse) - A high-performance Claude Code statusline tool written in Rust with Git integration, usage tracking, interactive TUI configuration, and Claude Code enhancement utilities.
   199â†’- [ccstatusline](https://github.com/sirmalloc/ccstatusline) by [sirmalloc](https://github.com/sirmalloc) - A highly customizable status line formatter for Claude Code CLI that displays model info, git branch, token usage, and other metrics in your terminal.
   200â†’- [claude-code-statusline](https://github.com/rz1989s/claude-code-statusline) by [rz1989s](https://github.com/rz1989s) - Enhanced 4-line statusline for Claude Code with themes, cost tracking, and MCP server monitoring.
   201â†’- [claude-powerline](https://github.com/Owloops/claude-powerline) by [Owloops](https://github.com/Owloops) - A vim-style powerline statusline for Claude Code with real-time usage tracking, git integration, custom themes, and more.
   202â†’- [claudia-statusline](https://github.com/hagan/claudia-statusline) by [Hagan Franks](https://github.com/hagan) - High-performance Rust-based statusline for Claude Code with persistent stats tracking, progress bars, and optional cloud sync. Features SQLite-first persistence, git integration, context progress bars, burn rate calculation, XDG-compliant with theme support (dark/light, NO_COLOR).
   203â†’
   204â†’<br>
   205â†’
   206â†’## Hooks ğŸª
   207â†’
   208â†’> Hooks are a powerful API for Claude Code that allows users to activate commands and run scripts at different points in Claude's agentic lifecycle.
   209â†’
   210â†’### General
   211â†’
   212â†’- [Britfix](https://github.com/Talieisin/britfix) by [Talieisin](https://github.com/Talieisin) - Claude outputs American spellings by default, which can have an impact on: professional credibility, compliance, documentation, and more. Britfix converts to British English, with a Claude Code hook for automatic conversion as files are written. Context-aware: handles code files intelligently by only converting comments and docstrings, never identifiers or string literals.
   213â†’- [CC Notify](https://github.com/dazuiba/CCNotify) by [dazuiba](https://github.com/dazuiba) - CCNotify provides desktop notifications for Claude Code, alerting you to input needs or task completion, with one-click jumps back to VS Code and task duration display.
   214â†’- [cchooks](https://github.com/GowayLee/cchooks) by [GowayLee](https://github.com/GowayLee) - A lightweight Python SDK with a clean API and good documentation; simplifies the process of writing hooks and integrating them into your codebase, providing a nice abstraction over the JSON configuration files.
   215â†’- [Claude Code Hook Comms (HCOM)](https://github.com/aannoo/claude-hook-comms) by [aannoo](https://github.com/aannoo) - Lightweight CLI tool for real-time communication between Claude Code sub agents using hooks. Enables multi-agent collaboration with @-mention targeting, live dashboard monitoring, and zero-dependency implementation. [NOTE: At the time of posting, this resource is a little unstable - I'm sharing it anyway, because I think it's incredibly promising and creative. I hope by the time you read this, it is production-ready.].
   216â†’- [claude-code-hooks-sdk](https://github.com/beyondcode/claude-hooks-sdk) by [beyondcode](https://github.com/beyondcode) - A Laravel-inspired PHP SDK for building Claude Code hook responses with a clean, fluent API. This SDK makes it easy to create structured JSON responses for Claude Code hooks using an expressive, chainable interface.
   217â†’- [claude-hooks](https://github.com/johnlindquist/claude-hooks) by [John Lindquist](https://github.com/johnlindquist) - A TypeScript-based system for configuring and customizing Claude Code hooks with a powerful and flexible interface.
   218â†’- [Claudio](https://github.com/ctoth/claudio) by [Christopher Toth](https://github.com/ctoth) - A no-frills little library that adds delightful OS-native sounds to Claude Code via simple hooks. It really sparks joy.
   219â†’- [TDD Guard](https://github.com/nizos/tdd-guard) by [Nizar Selander](https://github.com/nizos) - A hooks-driven system that monitors file operations in real-time and blocks changes that violate TDD principles.
   220â†’- [TypeScript Quality Hooks](https://github.com/bartolli/claude-code-typescript-hooks) by [bartolli](https://github.com/bartolli) - Quality check hook for Node.js TypeScript projects with TypeScript compilation. ESLint auto-fixing, and Prettier formatting. Uses SHA256 config caching for < 5ms validation performance during real-time editing.
   221â†’
   222â†’<br>
   223â†’
   224â†’## Slash-Commands ğŸ”ª
   225â†’
   226â†’> "Slash Commands are customized, carefully refined prompts that control Claude's behavior in order to perform a specific task"
   227â†’
   228â†’### General
   229â†’

This integration allows Claude to analyze repositories, answer technical questions, and help developers understand and improve their codebase through simple @mentions.
   146â†’- [claude-code-tools](https://github.com/pchalasani/claude-code-tools) by [Prasad Chalasani](https://github.com/pchalasani) - Well-crafted toolset for session continuity, featuring skills/commands to avoid compaction and recover context across sessions with cross-agent handoff between Claude Code and Codex CLI. The repository is intentionally minimal, containing only configuration templates for three primary systems: Claude Code, Serena, and Task Master.
   148â†’- [claudekit](https://github.com/carlrannaberg/claudekit) by [Carl Rannaberg](https://github.com/carlrannaberg) - Impressive CLI toolkit providing auto-save checkpointing, code quality hooks, specification generation and execution, and 20+ specialized subagents including oracle (gpt-5), code-reviewer (6-aspect deep analysis), ai-sdk-expert (Vercel AI SDK), typescript-expert and many more for Claude Code workflows.
   149â†’- [Container Use](https://github.com/dagger/container-use) by [dagger](https://github.com/dagger) - Development environments for coding agents. Enable multiple agents to work safely and independently with your preferred stack.
   150â†’- [ContextKit](https://github.com/FlineDev/ContextKit) by [Cihat GÃ¼ndÃ¼z](https://github.com/Jeehut) - A systematic development framework that transforms Claude Code into a proactive development partner. Features 4-phase planning methodology, specialized quality agents, and structured workflows that help AI produce production-ready code on first try.
   151â†’- [recall](https://github.com/zippoxer/recall) by [zippoxer](https://github.com/zippoxer) - Full-text search your Claude Code sessions. Run `recall` in terminal, type to search, Enter to resume. Alternative to `claude --resume`.
   152â†’- [Rulesync](https://github.com/dyoshikawa/rulesync) by [dyoshikawa](https://github.com/dyoshikawa) - A Node.js CLI tool that automatically generates configs (rules, ignore files, MCP servers, commands, and subagents) for various AI coding agents. Rulesync can convert configs between Claude Code and other AI agents in both directions.
   153â†’- [run-claude-docker](https://github.com/icanhasjonas/run-claude-docker) by [Jonas](https://github.com/icanhasjonas/) - A self-contained Docker runner that forwards your current workspace into a safe(r) isolated docker container, where you still have access to your Claude Code settings, authentication, ssh agent, pgp, optionally aws keys etc.
   154â†’- [stt-mcp-server-linux](https://github.com/marcindulak/stt-mcp-server-linux) by [marcindulak](https://github.com/marcindulak) - A push-to-talk speech transcription setup for Linux using a Python MCP server. Runs locally in Docker with no external API calls. Your speech is recorded, transcribed into text, and then sent to Claude running in a Tmux session.
   155â†’- [SuperClaude](https://github.com/SuperClaude-Org/SuperClaude_Framework) by [SuperClaude-Org](https://github.com/SuperClaude-Org) - A versatile configuration framework that enhances Claude Code with specialized commands, cognitive personas, and development methodologies, such as "Introspection" and "Orchestration".
   156â†’- [tweakcc](https://github.com/Piebald-AI/tweakcc) by [Piebald-AI](https://github.com/Piebald-AI) - Command-line tool to customize your Claude Code styling.
   157â†’- [Vibe-Log](https://github.com/vibe-log/vibe-log-cli) by [Vibe-Log](https://github.com/vibe-log) - Analyzes your Claude Code prompts locally (using CC), provides intelligent session analysis and actionable strategic guidance - works in the statusline and produces very pretty HTML reports as well. Easy to install and remove.
   158â†’- [viwo-cli](https://github.com/OverseedAI/viwo) by [Hal Shin](https://github.com/hal-shin) - Run Claude Code in a Docker container with git worktrees as volume mounts to enable safer usage of `--dangerously-skip-permissions` for frictionless one-shotting prompts. Allows users to spin up multiple instances of Claude Code in the background easily with reduced permission fatigue.
   159â†’- [VoiceMode MCP](https://github.com/mbailey/voicemode) by [Mike Bailey](https://github.com/mbailey) - VoiceMode MCP brings natural conversations to Claude Code. It supports any OpenAI API compatible voice services and installs free and open source voice services (Whisper.cpp and Kokoro-FastAPI).

>_ gh pr create --repo hesreallyhim/awesome-claude-code --head vtemian:add-claude-notes --title "feat: add claude-notes to Tooling section" --body "$(cat <<'EOF' ## Summary Adds [claude-notes](https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes) to the Tooling section. **claude-notes** is a Python CLI tool that transforms Claude Code transcript JSONL files into: - Terminal-viewable output with syntax highlighting - Standalone HTML files with styling and conversation structure Built with `uv` for fast package management and runnable via `uvx`. ## Changes - Added claude-notes entry to Tooling > General section (alphabetically ordered) EOF )" 1 lines

Vlad, you don't submit a PR directly. Use their automated issue template:
https://github.com/hesreallyhim/awesome-claude-code/issues/new?template=recommend-resource.yml
Based on the format, you'd describe claude-notes something like:
> [claude-notes](https://github.com/whitemonk/claude-notes) by [whitemonk](https://github.com/whitemonk) - CLI tool that transforms Claude Code transcript JSONL files into terminal-viewable output and HTML files for reviewing and sharing conversation history.
It would likely fit in their Tooling or similar utilities category.
Want me to fetch the CONTRIBUTING.md to see if there are additional requirements?
the repository is https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes
Got it, Vlad. Here's your submission:
Issue template link: https://github.com/hesreallyhim/awesome-claude-code/issues/new?template=recommend-resource.yml
Suggested entry:
> [claude-notes](https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes) by [vtemian](https://github.com/vtemian) - CLI tool that transforms Claude Code transcript JSONL files into terminal-viewable output and HTML files for reviewing and sharing conversation history.
Just fill out that issue form and they'll handle the rest automatically.
help me out here Thank you for recommending a resource to Awesome Claude Code! This form will guide you through the recommendation process. Please make sure that you have already reviewed the CONTRIBUTING document as well as the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.
Resource Guidelines:
Ensure...
Show more
help me out here Thank you for recommending a resource to Awesome Claude Code! This form will guide you through the recommendation process. Please make sure that you have already reviewed the CONTRIBUTING document as well as the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.
Resource Guidelines:
Ensure that your resource is unique and provides genuine value to Claude Code users. (Review the existing resources before submitting.) Avoid submitting resources that violate the Claude Code Usage Policy (to the best of your understanding). Make sure that the project does not violate the licensing rights of other independent developers. Recommendations will be closely scrutinized for security and potential risk. Although most recommendations are submitted by the authors, you may submit any resource that you love. Tips and Tricks for a Speedy Review:
Please provide clear installation AND uninstallation instructions for any installable resources. If your resource requires me to execute a bash script, you must provide me with a clearly annotated/commented version in which everything is documented clearly. I can read Bash, but it hurts my eyes after a while. Short examples or demos are tremendously helpful in the review process. If I can see it in action before I think about running it, you're way ahead of the curve. If your resource requires elevated access or "--dangerously-skip-permissions", please make sure the user is aware of this(!) If you are claiming that a resource improves Claude's capacity to perform some particular action - provide clear instructions explaining how to demonstrate it. Instead of listing 100 things that your framework/plugin/skill provides, better to pick one awesome thing it can do that makes it stand out, and explain how to validate that claim. That's not only helpful for me, but for any potential users. Ask Claude for a Candid Review: When I review your recommendation, most likely I will ask my assistant Claude Code to give me its opinion as well. I might say: "Please give a careful review of this repository and evaluate it from 1-10 on the following aspects: (i) code quality; (ii) security; (iii) documentation; (iv) functionality. Finally, give an overall score and determine whether you would recommend this resource." Something like that. Do that. What you do after that is up to you, just be aware that this is something I will be doing as well.
After submission, our automated system will validate whether your Issue is well-formed with respect to the requirements of the template, and post the results as a comment. (This is merely a formality and does not constitute a review.)
Let me review your project to help craft a solid submission.
ğŸ“„ README.md 112 lines 
1â†’# Claude Notes
     2â†’
     3â†’Transform Claude Code transcript JSONL files into readable terminal and HTML formats.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Overview
     6â†’
     7â†’Claude Notes is a command-line tool that converts Claude Code conversation transcripts (stored as JSONL files) into human-readable formats. It supports both terminal output with rich formatting and HTML export for web viewing.
     8â†’
     9â†’```bash
    10â†’uvx claude-notes show
    11â†’```
    12â†’
    13â†’https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ca710fb3-558a-4ce5-9bf5-e42c80caf2bf
    14â†’
    15â†’```bash
    16â†’uvx claude-notes show --format html --output conversations.html
    17â†’```
    18â†’
    19â†’https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e4cb9404-bdee-4a12-8e06-e1e2216b9165
    20â†’
    21â†’## Examples
    22â†’
    23â†’See rendered HTML output examples:
    24â†’
    25â†’- [Conversation Export](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes/blob/main/examples/conversations.html) - Full conversation with tool usage, code blocks, and timestamps
    26â†’
    27â†’The `examples/` directory also contains a [dark theme CSS](examples/example-dark-style.css) you can use to customize the HTML output.
    28â†’
    29â†’## Features
    30â†’
    31â†’- Terminal display with syntax highlighting and rich formatting
    32â†’- HTML export with navigation, timestamps, and professional styling
    33â†’- Interactive pager for browsing long conversations
    34â†’- Project discovery - automatically finds Claude projects
    35â†’- Humanized timestamps - shows "2 hours ago" instead of raw timestamps
    36â†’- Tool result formatting - properly displays Bash, Read, Edit, MultiEdit, and Grep tool usage
    37â†’- Navigation links - jump to specific messages in HTML output
    38â†’
    39â†’## Acknowledge
    40â†’
    41â†’This tool was heavily inspired by https://github.com/daaain/claude-code-log
    42â†’
    43â†’## Usage
    44â†’
    45â†’#### HTML Output
    46â†’
    47â†’```bash
    48â†’# Export to HTML file
    49â†’uvx claude-notes show --format html --output conversations.html
    50â†’
    51â†’# Print HTML to stdout
    52â†’uvx claude-notes show --format html
    53â†’```
    54â†’
    55â†’#### Terminal Output
    56â†’
    57â†’```bash
    58â†’# View conversations for current directory
    59â†’uvx claude-notes show
    60â†’
    61â†’# View conversations for specific project path
    62â†’uvx claude-notes show /path/to/project
    63â†’
    64â†’# Disable pager (show all at once)
    65â†’uvx claude-notes show --no-pager
    66â†’
    67â†’# Show raw JSON data
    68â†’uvx claude-notes show --raw
    69â†’```
    70â†’
    71â†’## HTML Features
    72â†’
    73â†’The HTML output includes:
    74â†’
    75â†’- **Message Navigation**: Each message has a clickable heading with anchor links
    76â†’- **Humanized Timestamps**: Shows when each message was created (e.g., "2 hours ago")
    77â†’- **Tool Result Formatting**: 
    78â†’  - Bash commands with syntax highlighting
    79â†’  - File operations (Read, Edit, MultiEdit)
    80â†’  - Search results (Grep)
    81â†’- **Responsive Design**: Works well on desktop and mobile
    82â†’- **Professional Styling**: Clean, readable typography
    83â†’
    84â†’## How It Works
    85â†’
    86â†’Claude Code stores conversation transcripts as JSONL files in `~/.claude/projects/`. Each line represents a message, tool use, or tool result. Claude Notes:
    87â†’
    88â†’1. Discovers Claude projects by scanning the projects directory
    89â†’2. Parses JSONL transcript files 
    90â†’3. Groups related messages by role continuity
    91â†’4. Formats tool usage and results appropriately
    92â†’5. Outputs in your chosen format (terminal or HTML)
    93â†’
    94â†’## Contributing
    95â†’
    96â†’1. Fork the repository
    97â†’2. Create a feature branch: `git checkout -b feature-name`
    98â†’3. Make your changes
    99â†’4. Test thoroughly
   100â†’5. Submit a pull request
   101â†’
   102â†’See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for detailed guidelines.
   103â†’
   104â†’## License
   105â†’
   106â†’MIT License - see [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.
   107â†’
   108â†’## Support
   109â†’
   110â†’- Report issues: [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes/issues)
   111â†’- Feature requests: [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes/discussions)
   112â†’
âš™ Glob
âš™ Glob

     2â†’name = "claude-notes"
     3â†’version = "0.1.8"
     4â†’description = "Transform Claude Code transcript JSONL files to terminal and HTML views"
     5â†’readme = "README.md"
     6â†’requires-python = ">=3.11"
     7â†’license = { text = "MIT" }
     8â†’authors = [
     9â†’    { name = "Claude Notes Contributors" }
    10â†’]
    11â†’keywords = ["claude", "ai", "transcript", "html", "terminal", "cli"]
    12â†’classifiers = [
    13â†’    "Development Status :: 4 - Beta",
    14â†’    "Environment :: Console",
    15â†’    "Intended Audience :: Developers",
    16â†’    "License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License",
    17â†’    "Operating System :: OS Independent",
    18â†’    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
    19â†’    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.11",
    20â†’    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.12",
    21â†’    "Topic :: Software Development",
    22â†’    "Topic :: Text Processing :: Markup :: HTML",
    23â†’    "Topic :: Utilities",
    24â†’]
    25â†’dependencies = [
    26â†’    "click>=8.1.0",
    27â†’    "rich>=13.7.0",
    28â†’]
    29â†’
    30â†’[project.urls]
    31â†’Homepage = "https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes"
    32â†’Repository = "https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes"
    33â†’Issues = "https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes/issues"
    34â†’Documentation = "https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes#readme"
    35â†’
    36â†’[project.scripts]
    37â†’claude-notes = "claude_notes.__main__:main"
    38â†’
    39â†’[project.optional-dependencies]
    40â†’animation = [
    41â†’    "asciinema>=2.3.0",
    42â†’]
    43â†’dev = [
    44â†’    "ruff>=0.1.0",
    45â†’    "pytest>=7.0.0",
    46â†’    "pytest-cov>=4.0.0",
    47â†’]
    48â†’
    49â†’[tool.uv]
    50â†’package = true
    51â†’
    52â†’[build-system]
    53â†’requires = ["hatchling"]
    54â†’build-backend = "hatchling.build"
    55â†’
    56â†’[tool.ruff]
    57â†’target-version = "py311"
    58â†’line-length = 120
    59â†’
    60â†’[tool.ruff.lint]
    61â†’select = [
    62â†’    "E",  # pycodestyle errors
    63â†’    "W",  # pycodestyle warnings
    64â†’    "F",  # pyflakes
    65â†’    "I",  # isort
    66â†’    "B",  # flake8-bugbear
    67â†’    "C4", # flake8-comprehensions
    68â†’    "UP", # pyupgrade
    69â†’]
    70â†’ignore = [
    71â†’    "E501", # line too long, handled by formatter
    72â†’    "B008", # do not perform function calls in argument defaults
    73â†’]
    74â†’
    75â†’[tool.ruff.format]
    76â†’quote-style = "double"
    77â†’indent-style = "space"
    78â†’
Here's what you need for the form, Vlad:
---

Resource Name

claude-notes

Resource URL

https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes

Category

Tooling (or Utilities if that's an option)

Description (short)

CLI tool that transforms Claude Code transcript JSONL files into readable terminal output and HTML files - useful for reviewing, sharing, and documenting conversations.

Installation Instructions

# Install and run with uvx (recommended - no permanent installation)
uvx claude-notes show


Or install permanently with pipx

pipx install claude-notes

Uninstallation Instructions

# If installed with pipx
pipx uninstall claude-notes


uvx doesn't install permanently - just stop using it

Key Feature to Highlight

One-command HTML export of Claude Code conversations 
uvx claude-notes show --format html --output conversation.html

This creates a navigable HTML document with:
  • Syntax-highlighted code blocks
  • Collapsible tool outputs (Bash, Read, Edit, Grep results)
  • Humanized timestamps
  • Anchor links for navigation

Live example: https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/vtemian/claude-notes/blob/main/examples/conversations.html

Demo

Your README already has two video demos embedded. Point to those.

Security/Permissions

  • No elevated permissions required
  • No --dangerously-skip-permissions needed
  • Read-only access to ~/.claude/projects/ (where Claude stores transcripts)
  • Pure Python, minimal dependencies (click, rich)

---
Want me to also run a self-review like they suggested? I can evaluate the code quality, security, documentation, and functionality.
A brief description of your resource (1-3 sentences maximum, no emojis) - follow the list's style - be descriptive, not promotional
Here's a description matching the list's style:
> CLI tool that converts Claude Code conversation transcripts (JSONL files from ~/.claude) into formatted terminal output or standalone HTML files with syntax highlighting, collapsible tool results, and navigation - useful for reviewing sessions or sharing conversations.
Or shorter:
> Converts Claude Code conversation transcripts to formatted terminal output or HTML files with syntax highlighting and collapsible tool results.
Validate Claims If you are submitting a complicated resource that gives Claude Code super-powers, suggest a low-friction way for me, or anyone, to prove it to themselves that what you're claiming is true. If you are submitting a plugin, skill, framework, or similar, this field is mandatory.
This is a straightforward utility, not a framework or skill. To validate: 
# 1. Run it in any directory where you've used Claude Code
uvx claude-notes show


2. You'll see your conversation history formatted in the terminal



3. Export to HTML and open in browser

uvx claude-notes show --format html --output test.html
open test.html

If you have Claude Code conversations in ~/.claude/projects/, it will find and display them. If not, you'll see "No conversations found" - which is also correct behavior.
Specific Prompt(s) Tell me what to say to Claude Code when I give it the task above. The more I have to figure things out for myself, the more likely it is that I will miss the unique value of your resource. So you are advised to be as specific as possible.
This field doesn't apply - claude-notes is a standalone CLI tool you run yourself, not something you tell Claude Code to use.
You run it directly in your terminal: 
uvx claude-notes show
uvx claude-notes show --format html --output conversation.html

It reads Claude Code's transcript files from ~/.claude/projects/ and formats them for viewing. No Claude Code interaction needed.

ğŸ¤– Analyze repo structure deeply
[{'type': 'text', 'text': 'Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the repository. Let me create a detailed analysis summary:\n\n---\n\n## Repository Analysis: claude-notes\n\n### 1. **File and Directory Structure**\n\n```\n/Users/whitemonk/projects/claude-notes/\nâ”œâ”€â”€ src/claude_notes/\nâ”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py (11 lines - package init, version 0.1.0)\nâ”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ __main__.py (28 lines - CLI entry point, Windows UTF-8 handling)\nâ”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ cli.py
Here's a comprehensive analysis of the claude-notes repository, Vlad:

Repository Overview


claude-notes is a Python CLI tool (475+ source lines across 11 modules) that transforms Claude Code's transcript JSONL files into viewable terminal output, HTML, and animated formats.

Directory Structure


claude-notes/
â”œâ”€â”€ src/claude_notes/           # Main package (7 modules, ~2,300 LOC)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ cli.py                  # CLI commands (475 lines)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ parser.py               # JSONL parsing (77 lines)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pager.py                # Terminal pager (306 lines)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ formatters/             # Output formatters (6 modules, ~1,500 LOC)
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ base.py             # Abstract base, tool result collection
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ factory.py          # Factory pattern
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ terminal.py         # Rich terminal output
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ html.py             # Standalone HTML (945 lines!)
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ animated.py         # Asciicast/GIF/MP4
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ tools.py            # 10 tool-specific formatters
â”œâ”€â”€ examples/                   # Rendered samples
â”œâ”€â”€ .github/workflows/          # CI/CD
â”œâ”€â”€ pyproject.toml              # Dependencies: click, rich
â”œâ”€â”€ Makefile                    # build, format, test
â””â”€â”€ dist/                       # Build artifacts

Architecture Highlights


ComponentPurpose
cli.pyPath encoding/decoding (Windows/Unix), project discovery, format selection
parser.pyJSONL line-by-line parsing with metadata extraction
pager.pyCross-platform less-like pager with j/k/space/b/g/G/q/h
base.pyMaps tool results to tool uses, groups messages by role
tools.py10 formatters: Bash, Read, Write, Edit, MultiEdit, Task, Grep, LS, TodoRead, TodoWrite

Key Design Patterns


  1. Factory Pattern - FormatterFactory creates terminal/html/animated formatters
  2. Registry Pattern - Tool formatters registered by tool name
  3. Template Method - Base formatter defines interface, subclasses implement

Dependencies


  • Core: click>=8.1.0, rich>=13.7.0
  • Optional: asciinema>=2.3.0 (for animation)
  • External tools: agg, ffmpeg, svg-term-cli (not in requirements)

Notable Observations


  1. No tests directory - make test only runs --help check
  2. Heavy HTML formatter - 945 lines with embedded CSS, navigation TOC
  3. Smart path encoding - Handles Windows drive letters (C: â†’ C--)
  4. Cross-platform terminal - termios/tty (Unix) vs msvcrt (Windows)
  5. Untracked files - ARCHITECTURE.md and CODE_STYLE.md not committed

Entry Point Flow


__main__.py â†’ cli.py:cli() â†’ list-projects | show
                                    â†“
                             TranscriptParser
                                    â†“
                             FormatterFactory
                                    â†“
                    Terminal | HTML | Animated | Raw

The codebase is well-organized with clear separation of concerns. The formatters package is the heaviest (65% of code), especially html.py and animated.py.
make it more like nof1. css: @import...
Show more
make it more like nof1. css: @import U+0000-00FF, U+0131, U+0152-0153, U+02BB-02BC, U+02C6, U+02DA, U+02DC, U+0304, U+0308, U+0329, U+2000-206F, U+20AC, U+2122, U+2191, U+2193, U+2212, U+2215, U+FEFF, U+FFFD; }
I see the nof1 aesthetic - IBM Plex Mono, terminal-style design, clean black/white with subtle noise texture, uppercase headers. Let me examine the current HTML formatter to understand what needs to change.
ğŸ“„ html.py 253 lines 
1â†’"""HTML formatter for Claude conversations."""
     2â†’
     3â†’import html
     4â†’import re
     5â†’from datetime import UTC, datetime
     6â†’from pathlib import Path
     7â†’from typing import Any
     8â†’
     9â†’from claude_notes.formatters.base import BaseFormatter
    10â†’
    11â†’
    12â†’def humanize_date(timestamp_str: str) -> str:
    13â†’    """Convert ISO timestamp to humanized format."""
    14â†’    try:
    15â†’        # Parse the ISO timestamp
    16â†’        dt = datetime.fromisoformat(timestamp_str.replace("Z", "+00:00"))
    17â†’        now = datetime.now(UTC)
    18â†’
    19â†’        # Calculate time difference
    20â†’        diff = now - dt
    21â†’
    22â†’        # Convert to local time for display
    23â†’        local_dt = dt.astimezone()
    24â†’
    25â†’        # Format based on time difference
    26â†’        total_seconds = diff.total_seconds()
    27â†’
    28â†’        if total_seconds < 60:
    29â†’            return "just now"
    30â†’        elif total_seconds < 3600:  # Less than 1 hour
    31â†’            minutes = int(total_seconds / 60)
    32â†’            return f"{minutes} minute{'s' if minutes != 1 else ''} ago"
    33â†’        elif total_seconds < 86400:  # Less than 1 day
    34â†’            hours = int(total_seconds / 3600)
    35â†’            return f"{hours} hour{'s' if hours != 1 else ''} ago"
    36â†’        elif total_seconds < 2592000:  # Less than 30 days
    37â†’            days = int(total_seconds / 86400)
    38â†’            return f"{days} day{'s' if days != 1 else ''} ago"
    39â†’        else:
    40â†’            # For older dates, show the actual date
    41â†’            return local_dt.strftime("%B %d, %Y at %I:%M %p")
    42â†’    except (ValueError, TypeError):
    43â†’        # Fallback for unparseable dates
    44â†’        return timestamp_str
    45â†’
    46â†’
    47â†’class HTMLFormatter(BaseFormatter):
    48â†’    """Format Claude conversations for HTML display."""
    49â†’
    50â†’    def __init__(self):
    51â†’        """Initialize the formatter."""
    52â†’        super().__init__()
    53â†’
    54â†’    def format_conversation(self, messages: list[dict[str, Any]], conversation_info: dict[str, Any]) -> str:
    55â†’        """Format and return a conversation as HTML."""
    56â†’        # Collect tool results
    57â†’        self._collect_tool_results(messages)
    58â†’
    59â†’        # Group messages by role continuity
    60â†’        grouped_messages = self._group_messages(messages)
    61â†’
    62â†’        # Build HTML
    63â†’        html_parts = []
    64â†’        html_parts.append('<div class="conversation">')
    65â†’
    66â†’        # Add conversation header if available
    67â†’        conversation_id = conversation_info.get("conversation_id", "unknown")
    68â†’        if conversation_id:
    69â†’            html_parts.append('<div class="conversation-header">')
    70â†’            html_parts.append(f'<h2 id="conv-{conversation_id}">Conversation {conversation_id}</h2>')
    71â†’            if conversation_info.get("start_time"):
    72â†’                html_parts.append(f'<div class="timestamp">{conversation_info["start_time"]}</div>')
    73â†’            html_parts.append("</div>")
    74â†’
    75â†’        # Display each group with headings and anchors
    76â†’        for i, group in enumerate(grouped_messages):
    77â†’            html_parts.append(self._format_message_group(group, i + 1))
    78â†’
    79â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
    80â†’        return "\n".join(html_parts)
    81â†’
    82â†’    def _format_message_group(self, messages: list[dict[str, Any]], message_number: int = None) -> str:
    83â†’        """Format a group of messages from the same role."""
    84â†’        if not messages:
    85â†’            return ""
    86â†’
    87â†’        # Get the role from the first message
    88â†’        first_msg = messages[0]
    89â†’        message_data = first_msg.get("message", {})
    90â†’        role = message_data.get("role", "unknown")
    91â†’
    92â†’        # Process each message separately but display as one group
    93â†’        message_parts = []
    94â†’
    95â†’        for msg in messages:
    96â†’            msg_content = []
    97â†’
    98â†’            # Handle tool results that are stored at the message level
    99â†’            if msg.get("type") == "tool_result":
   100â†’                continue
   101â†’
   102â†’            message_data = msg.get("message", {})
   103â†’            content = message_data.get("content", "")
   104â†’
   105â†’            if isinstance(content, str):
   106â†’                msg_content.append(self._format_text_content(content, role))
   107â†’            elif isinstance(content, list):
   108â†’                # Handle content array (e.g., text + tool uses)
   109â†’                for item in content:
   110â†’                    if isinstance(item, dict):
   111â†’                        if item.get("type") == "text":
   112â†’                            msg_content.append(self._format_text_content(item.get("text", ""), role))
   113â†’                        elif item.get("type") == "tool_use":
   114â†’                            msg_content.append(self._format_tool_use_html(item, msg))
   115â†’
   116â†’            # Join content for this message
   117â†’            if msg_content:
   118â†’                message_parts.append("".join(msg_content))
   119â†’
   120â†’        if not message_parts:
   121â†’            return ""
   122â†’
   123â†’        # Create message group HTML with heading and anchor
   124â†’        role_class = f"message-group {role}"
   125â†’        role_icon = "ğŸ‘¤" if role == "user" else "ğŸ¤–" if role == "assistant" else "âš™ï¸"
   126â†’        role_name = role.title()
   127â†’
   128â†’        html_parts = []
   129â†’
   130â†’        html_parts.append(f'<div class="{role_class}">')
   131â†’
   132â†’        # Add message header with role, anchor, and timestamp
   133â†’        header_parts = []
   134â†’        header_parts.append('<div class="message-header">')
   135â†’        header_parts.append(f'<h3 id="msg-{message_number}" class="message-title">')
   136â†’        header_parts.append(f"{role_icon} {role_name}")
   137â†’        header_parts.append(f'<a href="#msg-{message_number}" class="anchor-link">#</a>')
   138â†’        header_parts.append("</h3>")
   139â†’
   140â†’        # Add timestamp if available (use first message's timestamp for the group)
   141â†’        if messages and messages[0].get("timestamp"):
   142â†’            timestamp_str = messages[0]["timestamp"]
   143â†’            humanized = humanize_date(timestamp_str)
   144â†’            header_parts.append(f'<div class="message-timestamp">{humanized}</div>')
   145â†’
   146â†’        header_parts.append("</div>")
   147â†’        html_parts.extend(header_parts)
   148â†’
   149â†’        # Add message content
   150â†’        html_parts.append('<div class="message-content">')
   151â†’        for part in message_parts:
   152â†’            html_parts.append(part)
   153â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
   154â†’
   155â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
   156â†’        return "\n".join(html_parts)
   157â†’
   158â†’    def _get_message_preview(self, messages: list[dict[str, Any]], max_length: int = 50) -> str:
   159â†’        """Generate a preview of the message content for navigation."""
   160â†’        if not messages:
   161â†’            return "Empty message"
   162â†’
   163â†’        # Extract text content from the first message
   164â†’        first_msg = messages[0]
   165â†’        message_data = first_msg.get("message", {})
   166â†’        content = message_data.get("content", "")
   167â†’
   168â†’        preview_text = ""
   169â†’
   170â†’        if isinstance(content, str):
   171â†’            preview_text = content.strip()
   172â†’        elif isinstance(content, list):
   173â†’            # Look for text content in the list
   174â†’            for item in content:
   175â†’                if isinstance(item, dict) and item.get("type") == "text":
   176â†’                    text = item.get("text", "").strip()
   177â†’                    if text:
   178â†’                        preview_text = text
   179â†’                        break
   180â†’                elif isinstance(item, dict) and item.get("type") == "tool_use":
   181â†’                    tool_name = item.get("name", "Unknown Tool")
   182â†’                    preview_text = f"[{tool_name} tool usage]"
   183â†’                    break
   184â†’
   185â†’        # Clean up the preview text
   186â†’        if preview_text:
   187â†’            # Remove markdown formatting for preview
   188â†’            preview_text = re.sub(r"\*\*(.*?)\*\*", r"\1", preview_text)  # Remove bold
   189â†’            preview_text = re.sub(r"\*(.*?)\*", r"\1", preview_text)  # Remove italic
   190â†’            preview_text = re.sub(r"`(.*?)`", r"\1", preview_text)  # Remove code
   191â†’            preview_text = re.sub(r"#+\s*", "", preview_text)  # Remove headers
   192â†’
   193â†’            # Don't truncate for HTML - show full preview
   194â†’            return html.escape(preview_text)
   195â†’
   196â†’        return "No content"
   197â†’
   198â†’    def _format_text_content(self, content: str, role: str) -> str:
   199â†’        """Format text content with proper HTML escaping and markdown conversion."""
   200â†’        if not content.strip():
   201â†’            return ""
   202â†’
   203â†’        # Escape HTML
   204â†’        content = html.escape(content)
   205â†’
   206â†’        # Convert markdown to HTML
   207â†’        content = self._markdown_to_html(content)
   208â†’
   209â†’        # Handle special tags for user messages
   210â†’        if role == "user":
   211â†’            content = self._parse_special_tags_html(content)
   212â†’
   213â†’        return f'<div class="text-content">{content}</div>'
   214â†’
   215â†’    def _markdown_to_html(self, content: str) -> str:
   216â†’        """Convert basic markdown to HTML."""
   217â†’        # Bold **text**
   218â†’        content = re.sub(r"\*\*(.*?)\*\*", r"<strong>\1</strong>", content)
   219â†’
   220â†’        # Italic *text*
   221â†’        content = re.sub(r"\*(.*?)\*", r"<em>\1</em>", content)
   222â†’
   223â†’        # Code `code`
   224â†’        content = re.sub(r"`(.*?)`", r"<code>\1</code>", content)
   225â†’
   226â†’        # Headers
   227â†’        content = re.sub(r"^### (.*?)$", r"<h3>\1</h3>", content, flags=re.MULTILINE)
   228â†’        content = re.sub(r"^## (.*?)$", r"<h2>\1</h2>", content, flags=re.MULTILINE)
   229â†’        content = re.sub(r"^# (.*?)$", r"<h1>\1</h1>", content, flags=re.MULTILINE)
   230â†’
   231â†’        # Line breaks
   232â†’        content = content.replace("\n", "<br>\n")
   233â†’
   234â†’        return content
   235â†’
   236â†’    def _parse_special_tags_html(self, content: str) -> str:
   237â†’        """Parse special tags in content for HTML."""
   238â†’        # Replace command-message tags
   239â†’        content = re.sub(
   240â†’            r"<command-message>(.*?)</command-message>",
   241â†’            r'<span class="command-message">\1</span>',
   242â†’            content,
   243â†’            flags=re.DOTALL,
   244â†’        )
   245â†’
   246â†’        # Replace command-name tags
   247â†’        content = re.sub(
   248â†’            r"<command-name>(.*?)</command-name>", r'<span class="command-name">\1</span>', content, flags=re.DOTALL
   249â†’        )
   250â†’
   251â†’        # Replace system-reminder tags
   252â†’        content = re.sub(
   253â†’            r"
Now I understand the structure. The current CSS is in get_html_css(). I need to replace it with a nof1-inspired terminal aesthetic. Let me create the new CSS.

+ def get_html_css() -> str:
+ """Return CSS styles for HTML output - nof1-inspired terminal aesthetic."""
+ return """
+ <style>
+ @import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=IBM+Plex+Mono:wght@100;200;300;400;500;600;700&display=swap");
+
+ :root {
+ --background: #ffffff;
+ --surface: #ffffff;
+ --surface-elevated: #f8f9fa;
+ --foreground: #000000;
+ --foreground-muted: #333333;
+ --foreground-subtle: #666666;
+ --border: #000000;
+ --border-subtle: #cccccc;
+ --terminal-green: #00aa00;
+ --terminal-red: #cc0000;
+ --terminal-yellow: #b8860b;
+ --terminal-blue: #0000aa;
+ }
+
+ [data-theme="dark"] {
+ --background: #000000;
+ --surface: #0a0a0a;
+ --surface-elevated: #111111;
+ --foreground: #00ff00;
+ --foreground-muted: #00cc00;
+ --foreground-subtle: #00aa00;
+ --border: #00ff00;
+ --border-subtle: #006600;
+ --terminal-green: #00ff00;
+ --terminal-red: #ff0000;
+ --terminal-yellow: #ffff00;
+ --terminal-blue: #00ffff;
+ }
+
+ *, *:before, *:after {
+ box-sizing: border-box;
+ margin: 0;
+ padding: 0;
+ }
+
+ html, body {
+ height: 100%;
+ background: var(--background);
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ font-family: "IBM Plex Mono", monospace;
+ font-feature-settings: "cv02", "cv03", "cv04", "cv11";
+ line-height: 1.5;
+ letter-spacing: -0.02em;
+ }
+
+ /* Noise texture overlay */
+ body::before {
+ content: "";
+ position: fixed;
+ top: 0;
+ left: 0;
+ width: 100%;
+ height: 100%;
+ background-image: url("data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg viewBox='0 0 256 256' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%3E%3Cfilter id='noiseFilter'%3E%3CfeTurbulence type='fractalNoise' baseFrequency='0.6' numOctaves='4' stitchTiles='stitch'/%3E%3CfeColorMatrix type='saturate' values='0'/%3E%3C/filter%3E%3Crect width='100%25' height='100%25' filter='url(%23noiseFilter)' opacity='0.15'/%3E%3C/svg%3E");
+ background-size: 180px 180px;
+ pointer-events: none;
+ z-index: 1;
+ opacity: 0.5;
+ }
+
+ .conversation {
+ position: relative;
+ z-index: 2;
+ max-width: 900px;
+ margin: 0 auto;
+ padding: 40px 20px;
+ }
+
+ /* Headers - uppercase terminal style */
+ h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
+ font-family: "IBM Plex Mono", monospace;
+ font-weight: 700;
+ letter-spacing: 0.1em;
+ text-transform: uppercase;
+ line-height: 1.2;
+ }
+
+ .conversation-header {
+ margin-bottom: 40px;
+ padding-bottom: 20px;
+ border-bottom: 2px solid var(--border);
+ }
+
+ .conversation-header h2 {
+ margin: 0;
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ font-size: 1.1rem;
+ }
+
+ .timestamp {
+ color: var(--foreground-subtle);
+ font-size: 0.75rem;
+ margin-top: 8px;
+ text-transform: uppercase;
+ letter-spacing: 0.05em;
+ }
+
+ /* Navigation */
+ .message-nav, .conversation-nav {
+ background-color: var(--surface);
+ border: 1px solid var(--border);
+ padding: 20px;
+ margin-bottom: 30px;
+ }
+
+ .message-nav h3, .conversation-nav h2 {
+ margin: 0 0 15px 0;
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ font-size: 0.875rem;
+ border-bottom: 1px solid var(--border-subtle);
+ padding-bottom: 10px;
+ }
+
+ .message-toc, .conversation-toc {
+ list-style: none;
+ padding: 0;
+ margin: 0;
+ }
+
+ .message-toc li, .conversation-toc li {
+ margin-bottom: 4px;
+ }
+
+ .message-toc a, .conversation-toc a {
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ text-decoration: none;
+ padding: 6px 10px;
+ display: block;
+ font-size: 0.8rem;
+ border: 1px solid transparent;
+ transition: none;
+ }
+
+ .message-toc a:hover, .conversation-toc a:hover {
+ background-color: var(--foreground);
+ color: var(--background);
+ text-decoration: none;
+ }
+
+ /* Message sections */
+ .message-header {
+ margin: 50px 0 15px 0;
+ padding-bottom: 8px;
+ border-bottom: 1px solid var(--border);
+ }
+
+ .message-title {
+ margin: 0;
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ font-size: 0.875rem;
+ display: flex;
+ align-items: center;
+ gap: 8px;
+ }
+
+ .anchor-link {
+ color: var(--foreground-subtle);
+ text-decoration: none;
+ font-weight: normal;
+ font-size: 0.75rem;
+ }
+
+ .anchor-link:hover {
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ }
+
+ .message-timestamp {
+ color: var(--foreground-subtle);
+ font-size: 0.7rem;
+ font-weight: normal;
+ margin-top: 4px;
+ text-transform: uppercase;
+ letter-spacing: 0.03em;
+ }
+
+ .message-group {
+ margin-bottom: 30px;
+ }
+
+ .message-group.user {
+ border-left: 3px solid var(--foreground);
+ padding-left: 15px;
+ }
+
+ .message-group.assistant {
+ border-left: 3px solid var(--foreground-subtle);
+ padding-left: 15px;
+ }
+
+ .message-content {
+ flex: 1;
+ min-width: 0;
+ }
+
+ /* Back to top */
+ .back-to-top {
+ text-align: center;
+ margin: 50px 0 20px 0;
+ padding-top: 20px;
+ border-top: 1px solid var(--border);
+ }
+
+ .back-to-top a {

+ letter-spacing: 0.05em;
+ transition: none;
+ }
+
+ .back-to-top a:hover {
+ background-color: var(--foreground);
+ color: var(--background);
+ }
+
+ /* Text content */
+ .text-content {
+ margin-bottom: 15px;
+ font-size: 0.875rem;
+ line-height: 1.6;
+ }
+
+ .text-content h1, .text-content h2, .text-content h3 {
+ margin: 25px 0 12px 0;
+ color: var(--foreground);
+ }
+
+ .text-content h1 { font-size: 1rem; }
+ .text-content h2 { font-size: 0.9rem; }
+ .text-content h3 { font-size: 0.85rem; }

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>Claude Conversations</title>

<style>
@import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=IBM+Plex+Mono:wght@100;200;300;400;500;600;700&display=swap");

:root {
    --background: #ffffff;
    --surface: #ffffff;
    --surface-elevated: #f8f9fa;
    --foreground: #000000;
    --foreground-muted: #333333;
    --foreground-subtle: #666666;
    --border: #000000;
    --border-subtle: #cccccc;
    --terminal-green: #00aa00;
    --terminal-red: #cc0000;
    --terminal-yellow: #b8860b;
    --terminal-blue: #0000aa;
}

[data-theme="dark"] {
    --background: #000000;
    --surface: #0a0a0a;
    --surface-elevated: #111111;
    --foreground: #00ff00;
    --foreground-muted: #00cc00;
    --foreground-subtle: #00aa00;
    --border: #00ff00;
    --border-subtle: #006600;
    --terminal-green: #00ff00;
    --terminal-red: #ff0000;
    --terminal-yellow: #ffff00;
    --terminal-blue: #00ffff;
}

*, *:before, *:after {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;
}

html, body {
    height: 100%;
    background: var(--background);
    color: var(--foreground);
    font-family: "IBM Plex Mono", monospace;
    font-feature-settings: "cv02", "cv03", "cv04", "cv11";
    line-height: 1.5;
    letter-spacing: -0.02em;
}

/* Noise texture overlay */
body::before {
    content: "";
    position: fixed;
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 100%;
    background-image: url("data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg viewBox='0 0 256 256' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%3E%3Cfilter id='noiseFilter'%3E%3CfeTurbulence type='fractalNoise' baseFrequency='0.6' numOctaves='4' stitchTiles='stitch'/%3E%3CfeColorMatrix type='saturate' values='0'/%3E%3C/filter%3E%3Crect width='100%25' height='100%25' filter='url(%23noiseFilter)' opacity='0.15'/%3E%3C/svg%3E");
    background-size: 180px 180px;
    pointer-events: none;
    z-index: 1;
    opacity: 0.5;
}

.conversation {
    position: relative;
    z-index: 2;
    max-width: 900px;
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 40px 20px;
}

/* Headers - uppercase terminal style */
h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
    font-family: "IBM Plex Mono", monospace;
    font-weight: 700;
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    line-height: 1.2;
}

.conversation-header {
    margin-bottom: 40px;
    padding-bottom: 20px;
    border-bottom: 2px solid var(--border);
}

.conversation-header h2 {
    margin: 0;
    color: var(--foreground);
    font-size: 1.1rem;
}

ğŸ“„ cli.py L310-370 60 lines 
310â†’        # Generate HTML output
   311â†’        from claude_notes.formatters.factory import FormatterFactory
   312â†’        from claude_notes.formatters.html import get_extra_html_css, get_html_css
   313â†’
   314â†’        formatter = FormatterFactory.create_formatter("html")
   315â†’
   316â†’        # Collect all formatted content
   317â†’        html_parts = []
   318â†’        html_parts.append("<!DOCTYPE html>")
   319â†’        html_parts.append('<html lang="en">')
   320â†’        html_parts.append("<head>")
   321â†’        html_parts.append('<meta charset="UTF-8">')
   322â†’        html_parts.append('<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">')
   323â†’        html_parts.append("<title>Claude Conversations</title>")
   324â†’        html_parts.append(get_html_css())
   325â†’        html_parts.append(get_extra_html_css(style))
   326â†’        html_parts.append("</head>")
   327â†’        html_parts.append("<body>")
   328â†’        html_parts.append('<div class="container">')
   329â†’
   330â†’        # Add conversation navigation if multiple conversations
   331â†’        if len(conversations) > 1:
   332â†’            html_parts.append('<div class="conversation-nav">')
   333â†’            html_parts.append("<h2>Conversations</h2>")
   334â†’            html_parts.append('<ul class="conversation-toc">')
   335â†’            for i, conv in enumerate(conversations):
   336â†’                conv_id = conv["info"].get("conversation_id", f"conv-{i + 1}")
   337â†’                start_time = conv["info"].get("start_time", "Unknown time")
   338â†’                html_parts.append(f'<li><a href="#conv-{conv_id}">ğŸ“ Conversation {i + 1} ({start_time})</a></li>')
   339â†’            html_parts.append("</ul>")
   340â†’            html_parts.append("</div>")
   341â†’
   342â†’        for i, conv in enumerate(conversations):
   343â†’            # Order the messages based on user preference
   344â†’            ordered_messages = order_messages(conv["messages"], message_order)
   345â†’            html_content = formatter.format_conversation(ordered_messages, conv["info"])
   346â†’            html_parts.append(html_content)
   347â†’            if i < len(conversations) - 1:
   348â†’                html_parts.append('<hr style="margin: 40px 0; border: 1px solid #e1e5e9;">')
   349â†’
   350â†’        # Add back to top link
   351â†’        html_parts.append('<div class="back-to-top">')
   352â†’        html_parts.append('<a href="#top">â¬†ï¸ Back to Top</a>')
   353â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
   354â†’
   355â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
   356â†’        html_parts.append("</body>")
   357â†’        html_parts.append("</html>")
   358â†’
   359â†’        html_output = "\n".join(html_parts)
   360â†’
   361â†’        if output:
   362â†’            # Write to file
   363â†’            output_path = Path(output)
   364â†’            output_path.write_text(html_output, encoding="utf-8")
   365â†’            console.print(f"[green]HTML output written to: {output_path}[/green]")
   366â†’        else:
   367â†’            # Print to stdout
   368â†’            print(html_output)
   369â†’    elif format == "animated":

+ html_parts.append("</div>")
+ # Theme toggle JavaScript
+ html_parts.append("""<script>
+ function toggleTheme() {
+ const html = document.documentElement;
+ const currentTheme = html.getAttribute('data-theme');
+ const newTheme = currentTheme === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark';
+ html.setAttribute('data-theme', newTheme);
+ localStorage.setItem('theme', newTheme);
+ }
+ // Load saved theme or default to light
+ const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('theme') || 'light';
+ if (savedTheme === 'dark') {
+ document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 'dark');
+ }
+ </script>""")
+ html_parts.append("</body>")
+ html_parts.append("</html>")

Done, Vlad. I've updated the HTML output to use a nof1-inspired terminal aesthetic. Key changes:
CSS Changes (src/claude_notes/formatters/html.py:587-1039):
  • Font: IBM Plex Mono from Google Fonts
  • Color scheme: CSS variables with light (white/black) and dark (black/green terminal) modes
  • Noise texture: SVG-based grain overlay like nof1
  • Typography: Uppercase headers with letter-spacing
  • Borders: Solid black (light) / green (dark) - no rounded corners
  • Tool blocks: Terminal-style with colored headers (red=bash, green=read, yellow=edit, blue=grep)
  • Diffs: Semi-transparent colored backgrounds

HTML Changes (src/claude_notes/cli.py):
  • Added theme toggle button (top-right corner)
  • JavaScript for localStorage-persisted theme preference
  • Updated HR separators to use CSS variables

Features:
  • Click "Toggle Theme" to switch between light (nof1 daytime) and dark (terminal green-on-black) modes
  • Theme preference persists in localStorage
  • Print-friendly (hides noise texture and toggle)

The file is open in your browser. The styling matches the nof1 aesthetic - monospace throughout, terminal borders, uppercase headers, subtle noise texture.

analyse deeply how this is looking https://ampcode.com/threads/T-019b956a-f4e6-71b4-87fa-4162258d33ff it is more human
This is a significantly different approach, Vlad. Let me break down what ampcode does that makes it feel more "human":

Key Design Differences


1. Condensed Tool Displays as Pills

Instead of showing full tool output inline, they use compact chips: 
ğŸ” Use selection for find  1 match  in macos
ğŸ“„ macos/Sources/App/macOS/MainMenu.xib  L280-320
These are scannable - you see the action without the noise.

2. Collapsible Thinking Section

The > Thinking is collapsed by default. Users can expand if curious, but it doesn't interrupt the narrative flow.

3. Narrative-First Layout

The AI's explanatory text is prominent: > "Now let me look at how macOS-specific bindings are done and find the AppDelegate..."
Tool uses appear as supporting evidence, not the main content.

4. Proper Diff Blocks

  • File header with path + +6 line count badge + dismiss Ã—
  • @@ -288,8 +288,14 @@ hunk markers
  • Syntax-highlighted code (XML, Swift, Zig)
  • Yellow progress bar at bottom
  • Context lines in gray, additions in green

5. Metadata Sidebar

Right panel shows:
  • Public/Private status
  • Thread age, repo link
  • Model used (Opus 4.5)
  • CLI indicator
  • Prompt count, context usage (20% of 168k)
  • Files touched (5), lines changed (+26)
  • Labels, Reference Thread ID

6. Terminal Commands as Distinct Blocks

>_  zig build 2>&1 | head -50
Clear visual distinction from narrative text.

7. Structured Summary

Final summary with bold filenames and inline code for method names.

What We'd Need to Change


Currentampcode
Full tool output inlineCollapsed pills with expand
Flat structureNarrative + tools + diffs hierarchy
Basic diff coloringSyntax-highlighted diffs with headers
No metadataRich sidebar with stats
All visibleCollapsible sections

This isn't just CSS - it's a structural HTML change. Want me to prototype this approach?
yes. think how can we integrate as many features as possibles
Let me think through this systematically and then prototype.
ğŸ“‹ Todos
  • â— Design ampcode-inspired layout structure
  • â—‹ Implement two-column layout with metadata sidebar
  • â—‹ Create collapsible tool displays as pills
  • â—‹ Enhance diff blocks with headers and syntax highlighting
  • â—‹ Add collapsible thinking sections
  • â—‹ Style terminal commands distinctly
  • â—‹ Make dark theme the default
Let me map out the architecture:

Integration Plan

Key Implementation Changes

ğŸ“„ html.py L1-100 100 lines 
1â†’"""HTML formatter for Claude conversations."""
     2â†’
     3â†’import html
     4â†’import re
     5â†’from datetime import UTC, datetime
     6â†’from pathlib import Path
     7â†’from typing import Any
     8â†’
     9â†’from claude_notes.formatters.base import BaseFormatter
    10â†’
    11â†’
    12â†’def humanize_date(timestamp_str: str) -> str:
    13â†’    """Convert ISO timestamp to humanized format."""
    14â†’    try:
    15â†’        # Parse the ISO timestamp
    16â†’        dt = datetime.fromisoformat(timestamp_str.replace("Z", "+00:00"))
    17â†’        now = datetime.now(UTC)
    18â†’
    19â†’        # Calculate time difference
    20â†’        diff = now - dt
    21â†’
    22â†’        # Convert to local time for display
    23â†’        local_dt = dt.astimezone()
    24â†’
    25â†’        # Format based on time difference
    26â†’        total_seconds = diff.total_seconds()
    27â†’
    28â†’        if total_seconds < 60:
    29â†’            return "just now"
    30â†’        elif total_seconds < 3600:  # Less than 1 hour
    31â†’            minutes = int(total_seconds / 60)
    32â†’            return f"{minutes} minute{'s' if minutes != 1 else ''} ago"
    33â†’        elif total_seconds < 86400:  # Less than 1 day
    34â†’            hours = int(total_seconds / 3600)
    35â†’            return f"{hours} hour{'s' if hours != 1 else ''} ago"
    36â†’        elif total_seconds < 2592000:  # Less than 30 days
    37â†’            days = int(total_seconds / 86400)
    38â†’            return f"{days} day{'s' if days != 1 else ''} ago"
    39â†’        else:
    40â†’            # For older dates, show the actual date
    41â†’            return local_dt.strftime("%B %d, %Y at %I:%M %p")
    42â†’    except (ValueError, TypeError):
    43â†’        # Fallback for unparseable dates
    44â†’        return timestamp_str
    45â†’
    46â†’
    47â†’class HTMLFormatter(BaseFormatter):
    48â†’    """Format Claude conversations for HTML display."""
    49â†’
    50â†’    def __init__(self):
    51â†’        """Initialize the formatter."""
    52â†’        super().__init__()
    53â†’
    54â†’    def format_conversation(self, messages: list[dict[str, Any]], conversation_info: dict[str, Any]) -> str:
    55â†’        """Format and return a conversation as HTML."""
    56â†’        # Collect tool results
    57â†’        self._collect_tool_results(messages)
    58â†’
    59â†’        # Group messages by role continuity
    60â†’        grouped_messages = self._group_messages(messages)
    61â†’
    62â†’        # Build HTML
    63â†’        html_parts = []
    64â†’        html_parts.append('<div class="conversation">')
    65â†’
    66â†’        # Add conversation header if available
    67â†’        conversation_id = conversation_info.get("conversation_id", "unknown")
    68â†’        if conversation_id:
    69â†’            html_parts.append('<div class="conversation-header">')
    70â†’            html_parts.append(f'<h2 id="conv-{conversation_id}">Conversation {conversation_id}</h2>')
    71â†’            if conversation_info.get("start_time"):
    72â†’                html_parts.append(f'<div class="timestamp">{conversation_info["start_time"]}</div>')
    73â†’            html_parts.append("</div>")
    74â†’
    75â†’        # Display each group with headings and anchors
    76â†’        for i, group in enumerate(grouped_messages):
    77â†’            html_parts.append(self._format_message_group(group, i + 1))
    78â†’
    79â†’        html_parts.append("</div>")
    80â†’        return "\n".join(html_parts)
    81â†’
    82â†’    def _format_message_group(self, messages: list[dict[str, Any]], message_number: int = None) -> str:
    83â†’        """Format a group of messages from the same role."""
    84â†’        if not messages:
    85â†’            return ""
    86â†’
    87â†’        # Get the role from the first message
    88â†’        first_msg = messages[0]
    89â†’        message_data = first_msg.get("message", {})
    90â†’        role = message_data.get("role", "unknown")
    91â†’
    92â†’        # Process each message separately but display as one group
    93â†’        message_parts = []
    94â†’
    95â†’        for msg in messages:
    96â†’            msg_content = []
    97â†’
    98â†’            # Handle tool results that are stored at the message level
    99â†’            if msg.get("type") == "tool_result":
   100â†’                continue
Let me create a comprehensive redesign. I'll rewrite the HTML formatter with the ampcode-inspired approach.
ğŸ’¾ html.py +1390 lines (new file) 
"""HTML formatter for Claude conversations - ampcode-inspired design."""

import html
import re
from datetime import UTC, datetime
from pathlib import Path
from typing import Any

from claude_notes.formatters.base import BaseFormatter


def humanize_date(timestamp_str: str) -> str:
    """Convert ISO timestamp to humanized format."""
    try:
        dt = datetime.fromisoformat(timestamp_str.replace("Z", "+00:00"))
        now = datetime.now(UTC)
        diff = now - dt
        total_seconds = diff.total_seconds()

        if total_seconds < 60:
+1370 more lines
Now let me test the build and generate a sample.
>_ make format && make test 10 lines 
uv run ruff format
1 file reformatted, 11 files left unchanged
Running basic CLI functionality test...

This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The summary below covers the earlier portion of the conversation.
Analysis: Let me go through the conversation chronologically:
  1. Initial Request: User asked to "deeply analyse the current repo structure" of the claude-notes project.

  1. My Response: I used an Explore agent to thoroughly analyze the repository. The analysis revealed:
  • claude-notes is a Python CLI tool that transforms Claude Code transcript JSONL files into viewable formats (terminal, HTML, animated)
  • Key modules: cli.py (475 lines), parser.py (77 lines), pager.py (306 lines)
  • Formatters package: base.py, factory.py, terminal.py, html.py (945 lines), animated.py, tools.py
  • Dependencies: click, rich, optional asciinema
  • Build system: uv, hatchling

  1. Second Request: User asked to make the HTML output "more like nof1" and provided:
  • A massive CSS file from nof1 website (Tailwind-based)
  • A screenshot showing the nof1 design aesthetic

  1. My Response: I completely rewrote the CSS in html.py to match nof1's terminal aesthetic:
  • IBM Plex Mono font
  • Black/white color scheme with dark mode support (green terminal colors)
  • Noise texture overlay
  • Uppercase headers with letter-spacing
  • Terminal-style borders
  • Added theme toggle button with JavaScript for localStorage persistence

  1. Third Request: User asked to "commit and push. launch a new version"

  1. My Actions:
  • Updated version from 0.1.4 to 0.1.5 in pyproject.toml and __init__.py
  • Committed with message about nof1-inspired terminal aesthetic
  • Pushed to GitHub
  • Built the package
  • Tried to publish but got "Missing credentials" error

  1. Fourth Request: User asked to analyze ampcode.com thread viewer deeply, noting "it is more human" and provided 3 screenshots showing:
  • Two-column layout with sidebar
  • Collapsible thinking section
  • Tool uses as compact pills (search, file reads)
  • Diff blocks with file headers and colored lines
  • Terminal commands with >_ prompt
  • Metadata sidebar (stats, files modified)
  • Narrative-first design

  1. My Analysis: I provided detailed breakdown of ampcode's design:
  • Condensed tool displays as pills
  • Collapsible thinking section
  • Narrative-first layout
  • Proper diff blocks with syntax highlighting
  • Metadata sidebar
  • Terminal commands as distinct blocks

  1. Fifth Request: User said "yes. think how can we integrate as many features as possibles"

  1. My Response: I completely rewrote html.py with ampcode-inspired design:
  • New HTMLFormatter class with stats tracking
  • Title extraction from first user message
  • Sidebar generation with stats (files, lines, tools)
  • Collapsible thinking blocks using <details>
  • Tool formatters rewritten as pills/collapsible elements
  • Terminal blocks with >_ prompt styling
  • Diff blocks with headers, line counts, progress bars
  • Dark theme by default, light theme option
  • Two-column grid layout

  1. Final State: Code was formatted and tests passed. User needs to generate HTML and review output.

Key files modified:
  • /Users/whitemonk/projects/claude-notes/src/claude_notes/formatters/html.py - Complete rewrite
  • /Users/whitemonk/projects/claude-notes/src/claude_notes/cli.py - Added theme toggle
  • /Users/whitemonk/projects/claude-notes/pyproject.toml - Version bump
  • /Users/whitemonk/projects/claude-notes/src/claude_notes/__init__.py - Version bump

Summary:
  1. Primary Request and Intent:

  1. Key Technical Concepts:
  • Claude Code JSONL transcript parsing and formatting
  • HTML/CSS terminal aesthetic design (IBM Plex Mono, CSS variables, noise texture)
  • Two-column grid layout with sticky sidebar
  • Collapsible <details>/<summary> elements for tool outputs and thinking blocks
  • Statistics tracking (files read/edited, lines added/removed, tool calls)
  • Theme toggling with localStorage persistence
  • Tool formatters: Bash (terminal blocks), Read/Grep (pills), Edit (diff blocks), TodoWrite (checkboxes)

         def __init__(self):
             super().__init__()
             self.stats = {
                 "files_read": set(),
                 "files_edited": set(),
                 "lines_added": 0,
                 "lines_removed": 0,
                 "tool_calls": 0,
                 "searches": 0,
                 "bash_commands": 0,
             }

All ampcode-inspired features have been implemented, Vlad. The HTML file is now open in your browser. Here's what's included:
Implemented Features:
  1. Two-column layout - Content on left, sticky sidebar on right
  2. Metadata sidebar - Thread age, file count, line changes (+/-), tool call count, modified files list
  3. Collapsible tool pills - Read, Grep, Write, Task tools appear as compact expandable pills
  4. Diff blocks - File headers, line counts, progress bars showing additions/deletions ratio
  5. Terminal blocks - Bash commands with >_ prompt styling
  6. Thinking sections - Collapsed by default with toggle
  7. Dark theme default - GitHub dark-inspired palette with light theme toggle
